comments.content:
As usual, don't know the original name and can't state if it's a font or a custom lettering. Closest approximation I have for the moment is [Boston Truckstyle](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415062205/http:/www.letterheadfonts.com/fonts/bostontruckstyle.php) with a way-off /S...  
More loosely similar: [Tonic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415062205/http:/www.letterheadfonts.com/fonts/tonic.php), [Dialog](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415062205/http:/www.dafont.com/dialog.font)

Gavin - When you post something like this here, it is often helpful to tell us the source and, if known, date.

In this case, a very old Proctor & Gamble product with two O's that are _very_ different makes it clear that this was a hand drawn label. No font involved. Ryuk had provided modern alternatives.

Late 19th or early 20th century artwork in the form of a trademark. The most interesting features are the median spurs, the terminals on \_S\_ and the leg on the \_R\_.  
Median spurs were usually used on Tuscan, i.e. split or fishtail terminal fonts, rather than ones with flat terminals.  
A font in the latter style was digitized by Dan X. Solo under the name Cavalcade.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415062205im_/http:/typophile.com/files/CavalcadeSoloDoverCircusAlphabetsBookAsIvorySoap_4344.jpg)
 Unfortunately the only legitimate way to get this font is by purchase of a new or used copy of "24 Circus Display Fonts (Dover Electronic Display Fonts) (CD-ROM and Book)"  
Previous discussion of a median spur non-Tuscan font [http://typophile.com/node/116784](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415062205/http:/typophile.com/node/116784 "http://typophile.com/node/116784")  
The trademark could be expanded to make an attractive font, pehraps with plain and rimmed variations.  
Don

Ryuk suggested some modern alternatives. You could also look at three fonts by Michael Hagemann reviving 19th century typefaces: Cowboy Western

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415062205im_/http:/typophile.com/files/CowboyWesterInUseAsIvorySoap_6243.jpg)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/cowboy-western/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415062205/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/cowboy-western/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/cowboy-western/")  
Miss Scarlett, which is a Tuscan  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415062205im_/http:/typophile.com/files/MissScarlettInUseAsIvorySoap_5416.jpg)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/miss-scarlett/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415062205/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/miss-scarlett/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/miss-scarlett/")  
and Tenderfoot, which has terminals on the \_S\_ that are very similar to the ones in the Ivory Soap Trademark if they are rotated 90 degrees 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415062205im_/http:/typophile.com/files/TenderfootInUseAsIvorySoap_4688.jpg)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/tenderfoot/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415062205/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/tenderfoot/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/tenderfoot/")  
Don
Adding Solotype Olympian (no sample) to the list.

Dan X. Solo's Olympian

Don
